title: Stability Analysis of Fractional-Order Induction Motor Speed Controlled System
abstract: Stability is very important in control system design and analysis. This paper presents the stability analysis of the three-phase induction motor speed controlled system with the fractional-order proportional-integral-derivative (FOPID) controller designed by the cuckoo search (CS). Matignon's stability theorem is one of the most efficient and easiest approaches for stability analysis of the fractional control system. In this paper, Matignon's stability theorem associated with Riemann surface and Riemann sheets is conducted for stability analysis of the considered fractionalorder control system. As results, it was found that the threephase induction motor speed controlled system with the FOPID controller is stable according to the Matignon's stability conditions. The system stability can be assured by the responses of the controlled system.

sections.title: I. INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
In control context, stability is one of the most important topics for design and analysis. For the fractional control based on the fraction calculus, there are several approaches for stability analysis of the fractional-order linear time invariant (FOLTI) systems  [1] ,  [2] , for example, robust stability  [3] , bounded input-bounded output (BIBO) stability  [4] , internal stability  [5] , root-locus  [6] , robust controllability  [7]  and robust observability  [8] . For fractional nonlinear systems, Mittag-Leffer stability  [9]  and Chaotic attractors  [10]  can be utilized for stability analysis. By literature reviews, one of the most efficient and easiest approaches for stability analysis of the FOLTI systems is the Matignon's stability theorem  [4] ,  [8] ,  [11] . Associated with the Riemann surface and Riemann sheets  [12] , Matignon's stability conditions can easily utilized for stability analysis of the FOLTI systems.

From our previous work, the optimal fractional-order proportional-integral-derivative (FOPID or PI λ D µ ) controller of the three-phase induction motor speed control system has been optimized by the cuckoo search (CS)  [13] . However, the stability of such the system does not be analyzed yet. In this paper, the stability analysis of the three-phase induction motor speed controlled system with the FOPID controller designed by the CS is thus presented based on the Matignon's stability theorem associated with the Riemann surface and Riemann sheets. This paper is organized as follows. After an introduction is given in section I, the fractional control system is described in section II. Matignon's stability is illustrated in section III. Results and discussions of the stability analysis of the three-phase induction motor speed controlled system with the FOPID controller is provided in section IV. Finally, conclusion is followed in section V.

sections.title: A. Fractional Calculus
sections.text:
A generalization of integration and differentiation can be represented by the non-integer order fundamental operator

, where a and t are the limits of the operator. The continuous integro-differential operator is defined as expressed in  (1) , where    stands for the order of operation. Under zero initial conditions for order  (0 <  < 1), the Laplace transform of the non-integer order fundamental operator in (1) can be expressed in  (2) .

sections.title: B. Fractional LTI System
sections.text: A general fractional-order system can be described by a fractional differential equation as expressed in (3) with zero initial conditions or by the corresponding transfer function of incommensurate real orders as stated in (4)  [1] ,  [14] , where a k (k = 0,…,n), b k (k = 0,…,m) are constant (or coefficient) and a k (k = 0,…,n), b k (k = 0,…,m) are arbitrary real numbers. In general, the fractional-orders are  n >  n-1 >  >  0 and  m >  m-1 >  >  0 . The incommensurate order system in (4) can be rewritten in commensurate form by the multi-valued transfer function as expressed in (5)  [6] . Every FOLTI system can be expressed in the form  (5) . Domain of the commensurate transfer function form H(s) definition can be analyzed on the Riemann surface with v Riemann sheets  [12] .

sections.title: C. FOPID Controller
sections.text:
The FOPID (or PI  D  ) controller was firstly proposed by Podlubny in 1994  [15] ,  [16] . It possesses five tuning parameters: proportional gain (K p ), integration gain (K i ), derivative gain (K d ), integration order () and derivative order (). The FOPID can be described by the differential equation as expressed in  (6) , where e(t) is the error signal regarded as controller input, u(t) is the control signal regarded as the controller output and fractional-orders  and   0. By taking the Laplace transform, the FOPID can be rewritten as expressed in  (7) .

III. MATIGNON'S STABILITY By using the branch point and the branch cut in complex plane, the Riemann surface of multi-valued function w = s 1/v in Fig.  1(a) , where v  N (v = 1, 2, 3,…), can be transformed into the v Riemann sheets in Fig.  1(b) , where sector -/v < arg(w)  /v corresponding to the first (or principal)

Riemann sheet  [1] ,  [4] ,  [8] ,  [11] . The stability region of the fractional-order system can be performed by the first Riemann sheet on the complex wplane. In the fractional case, the stability is different from the integer one. Interesting notion is that a stable fractional system may have roots in right half of complex w-plane as visualized in Fig.  2 . For the case of commensurate order systems, whose characteristic equation is a polynomial of the complex variable  = s  , the stability condition is expressed in  (8) , where  i are the roots of the characteristic polynomial P(s  ) = 0. A commensurate order system, described by a rational transfer function in  (9) , where w = s q , q   + , (0 < q < 2), is stable if and only if the stability condition stated in (  10 ) is satisfied, where w i are the roots of the characteristic polynomial P(w) = 0.

Referring to (4), the characteristic equation of the fractional order system can be formulated in  (11) . It may be rewritten as  (12) , where u i and v i are the integer numbers. Then, it can be transformed into the w-plane as  (13) , where w = s 1/m and m is the least common multiple (LCM) of v i .

Let |arg(w i )| be the absolute phase angle of all roots w i . Roots in the s-plane have corresponding roots in the w-plane by the transformation s = w m . The condistion for stability is /2m < |arg(w i )| < /m. Condition for oscillation or undamped response is |arg(w i )| = /2m, otherwise the system is unstable. This means that if there is not root in the unstable region of the w-plane, the system will always be stable  [1] ,  [4] ,  [8] ,  [11] .

sections.title: IV. RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONS
sections.text: Based on Matignon's stability theorem associated with Riemann surface and Riemann sheets, the stability analysis of the three-phase induction motor speed controlled system with the FOPID controller designed by the CS is presented in this section. The considered three-phase induction motor speed control system is represented by the block diagram shown in Fig.  3 .

3-Phase Induction Motor Fig.  3 . Three-phase induction motor control system with FOPID.

Referring to Fig.  3 , the closed loop transfer function is formulated as stated in  (14) . From our previous work  [13] , the mathematical model of the three-phase induction motor, G p (s), and that of the FOPID controller designed by the CS, G c (s), are expressed in (  15 ) and (  16 ), respectively. Therefore, the closed loop transfer function in (  14 ) can be rewritten as stated in (17). Details of FOPID controller designed by the CS can be found in  [13] .

The characteristic equation and the corresponding commensurate characteristic equation of the considered system are performed in (  18 ) and (  19 ). Once w = s 1/100 and m =100 (LCM), a polynomial of complex variable w is then obtained as expressed in (20).

Some poles are summarized in Table  I . The Riemann surface of w = s 1/100 is depicted in Fig.  4 . 391 poles are then plotted in w-plane as shown in Fig.  5 . Referring to Table I and Fig.  5 , it was found that all poles are satisfy the condition |arg(w i )| > /2m > /200 radian = 0.0157 radian ( 0.9 degree). It means that the considered threephase induction motor speed controlled system with the FOPID controller designed by the CS is stable. The stability of the three-phase induction motor speed controlled system with the FOPID controller can be assured by its unit-step input tracking and unit-step load regulating responses plotted in Fig.  6  and Fig.  7 . Form both Fig.  6  and Fig.  7 , All responses are converged to equilibrium levels as t  . This implies that the three-phase induction motor speed controlled system with the FOPID controller is stable according to the BIBO stability  [4] . Normalized motor speed Fig. 6. sections.title: 
sections.text: V. CONCLUSIONS The stability analysis of the three-phase induction motor speed controlled system with the FOPID controller designed by the CS has been presented in this paper. The considered system has been classified as the FOLTI system. By utilizing the Matignon's stability theorem associated with Riemann surface and Riemann sheets, the fraction (incommensurate) order system model could be transformed into the commensurate order model by using the multi-valued transfer function. With this approach, the stability of any FOLTI system could by effectively and easily analyzed. For the considered FOLTI system, the three-phase induction motor speed controlled system with the FOPID controller designed by the CS is stable according to the Matignon's stability conditions. This stability has been assured by the responses of the controlled system according to the BIBO stability.
(a) Riemann surface (b) Complex w-plane Fig. 1. Correspondence between Riemann surface and Riemann sheets.
Stability regions of the fractional order system.
Fig. 4. Riemann surface of w = s 1/100 .
